label: TRAINING
data_answer: Saburo's relationship with his father is very unique in that as he grows in age, so does their relationship. At the beginning of the story, Saburo describes himself joining the track and field team; however, his father wasn't too excited to hear that he had only joined to run one part, the 800 meter. Thier relationship at this point is exemplified when he and his father are about to go and practice, "[I] wished [my] father were like [my] friends' fathers: sun-browned, guffawing men who ruffled children's hair with affectionate ease." This shows that his experiences with his dad are not too thoughful and easy to remember. At this point, thier relationship isn't at its greatest possilbilty, but when he decides to quit the track and field team and mainly focus on college and education, their relationship gets to a new level. As he grows older and is focused more oneducation, their relationship improves becasue they have a new found passion that both of them enjoy. The whole time, their relationship needed a focus on something they both would enjoy, not just one, which is why they bonded better when they could talk about science, "...thier conversations were no longer awkward. Any conversational opening inevitably led to a lecture on astronomy."

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Saburo's relationship with his father is a distant one, as in the passage, Saburo "wished his father were like his friends' fathers: sun-browned, guffawing men who ruffled children's hair with affectionate ease." From this quote, you can conclude that his father isn't very affectionate or intimate with him. Furthermore, despite his father's support for Saburo, "Saburo's father never attended Saburo's track competitions." However, it can also be inferred that his father did care about him, despite the distance, as "he always inquired after the [track] results at dinner" and after Saburo stopped running, "he sensed his father had enjoyed and wished to continue [the track sessions]." However, as the years passed, Saburo and his father slowly bonded over intellectual conversations in areas of science, as "now that Saburo was an adult, their conversations were no longer awkward."

data_answer: Saburo does not understand what his father has gone through, since his father has seen war. Saburo's father cares about Saburo. Even though he never attends his track meets because he cares more about his performance than results, he tries to help Saburo improve by taking him to Kaigane Station and makes him run whenever Saburo does not have practice. Saburo never realizes how passionate his father really is until he quit the track team, and when he talks to him about astronomy. Also, he finally imagines what his father had gone through during war.

data_answer: Saburo and his father's relationship begins as awkward and disconnected. "As far as Saburo knew, he had not been a track man in his youth." data_answer: Saburo and his father's relationship was never as Saburo wanted. His father was a strict and down-to-earth kind of man, so it seemed. Examples of this would be that he was never really affectionate with his son; he never really played with him when he was younger and he also was very stern about his son becoming successful, and not making it a competition against others, even though others may think that way. Over the years, however, when Saburo became an adult and was moving onto college he thought that his relationship with his father had actually suffered because they werent spending time going out and practicing his running times, but actually it was just the same, maybe even better. They began holding conversations about astronomy, and other science. Saburo realized his father had a passionate side.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Both Saburo and his father truly love each other, but they labor under the awkwardness of their slightly distanced father son relationship until Saburo's running brings them together again. The love Saburo's father holds for him is emphasized in his inquiries after Saburo's results at dinner, and his "interest in his son's times" rather than "in his rankings". Saburo's father clearly loves him and cares more about Saburo's results as an expression of this love, instead of comparing him to the other runners. However, there is also a slight strain in their relationship during Saburo's adolescence, as exemplified by Saburo's wihs that "his father were like his friends' fater: sun-browned, guffawing men who ruffled children's hair with affectionate ease." Saburo clearly dreams of a more openly emotional and affectionate father while he is in high school, which is perhaps the only point of contention in his relationship with his father, but he later overcomes even this, when, as an adult, "their conversations [are] no longer awkward."

data_answer: Although Saburo never had a demonstrative, affectionate relationship with his father, his father clearly loved him. His father was always willing and able to help him practice his running. Although some fathers emphasize vicotry and competition, Saburo's father told him that "Remember, it doesn't matter who's in front of you. Beating your own time's all that matters." As years progressed, Saburo eventually found that "the old man's voice rose with fervor, and he came to a full stop in order to make his point." He learned that his fathers heart wasn't ice, but rather a living, beating organ capable of loving his own son.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Saburo's relationship with his father was very tenative and awkward at first. When Saburo was in high school, the two had very little common ground or passions. They were both forced to move out of their comfort zones and connect on something that was new and different for both of them: track. This crucial bonding exercise allowed for important teaching moments between the father and son, as well as providing a basis to develop a deeper relationship and a mutual understanding. For instance, when the passage starts off, Saburo says that he had been "too young to remember what his father had been like in peacetime" (Waters). The activity enabled the father to son relationship to strengthen and develop further. It began as "awkward and silent," but began to transition into a beautiful and healthy relationship. As Saburo began to mature and grow, he came to understand and share some of his father's differences and unique passions. The activity of running at the track served as a basis to build upon a once tenative and budding relationship into one that had "compelete harmony" and "a passionate side" (Waters).

data_answer: The relationship between Saburo and his father is extremely professional. He often encourages Saburo to improve his time by focusing on himself, not those who he is racing. Although he never attends his meets, Saburo's father continues to support his goal by assisting him in practicing and is always curious about how he did that day at the meet. But, Saburo yearns for a more casual and closer relationship with his father while he is a teenager in that, "He wished his father were like his friends' fathers: sun-browned, guffawing men who ruffled children's hair with affectionate ease". Saburo is jealous of his peers' relationships with their dads because there was never awkward tension, silence, and they show their love in different ways than him and his own father.

label: TRAINING
data_answer: Saburo's relationship with his father is quite detached, initially. When Saburo introduces the fact that he is going to run eight hundred meters, a short-distance event, his father merely answers with "eight hundred meters? Is that all?". However, his father expresses recognition towards Saburo's goals when he states "'I'll be taking you out to Kaigane Station to clock your runs". The first time his father displays interest and a willingness to assist in Saburo's sport, sparks appreciation in Saburo, however, he questions it as his father is "old" and "an academic". Although their rides to the station are "awkward and silent", it is not until they reach their destination where Saburo feels "complete harmony between them". Saburo and his father's diversities are woven into one when they finally discover a mutality to bond over. Combined with the efforts of both father and son, they become able-bodied in establishing a comforting peace and calming nature between the two of them. When Saburo grows older and is introduced to the land of academics, he finds their conversations are "no longer awkward", and he learns to appreciate his father's perspective and the diverse aspects to him he had never known. The mutual efforts on behalf of the two of them to not only understand one another, but to actively involve themselves in one another's passions, grants access to the healthy and wholesome relationship that truly emerges in Saburo's later life.

His father could not attend his son's competition, but he was always concerned at how he was doing, and he supported his son's dedication in track. Even though Saburo's friends' fathers ruffling their children's hair in affection was something he cannot experience, Saburo feels in harmony with his father when he trains his track time. They are in a mutual, but good, relationship with each other.

data_answer: Saburo, initially, has an awkward relationship with his father. As Waters writes, "It was awkward and silent in the streetcar, just the two of them," and, "He wished his father were like his friends' fathers: sun-browned, guffawing men who ruffled children's hair with affectionate ease," she is showing that Saburo wishes his father was someone different. Later in the story, however, Waters writes, "Now that Saburo was an adult, their conversations were no longer awkward," and, "His father, he realized, had a passionate side." In this, Waters tries to convey to the reader that Saburo has experienced a change in feelings toward his father; he is now able to enjoy his father's company without the awkwardness.

label: VALIDATION
data_answer: The relationship of Saburo and his father was awkward and strained at first. Saburo described that his father had a stoic nature because he came from the war and helped rebuild Japan from ashes. After Saburo joined the track and field team, his father offered to take him to Kaigane Station to clock his runs. Although Saburo's father never attended his competitions, he always "inquired after the results at dinner." Saburo simply stated that his father "was an academic" to justify why his father never attended the competitions. The rides to Kaigane Station was often silent: "they sat gingerly side by side in the streetcar.. It was awkward and silent." Because of this, Saburo often "wished his father were like his friends' fathers: sun-browned, guffawing men who ruffled children's hair with affectionate ease." Even though their relationship was often awkward and tense, Saburo's father always encouraged Saburo to not think about how other runners do during the race; he encouraged Saburo to focus on beating his time so that he can improve. At the end, Saburo realized that his father was a very passionate person, whose "voice rose with fervor, [coming] to a full stop in order to make his point," and their relationship was more at ease, allowing them to have conversations that were no longer awkward.

data_answer: Saburo's relationship with his father is a very traditional one; it is a prime example of how in Asian culture one must show the utmost respect to one's elders. The "awkward and silent" experience that Saburo and his father shared in the streetcar and how Saburo "wished his father were like his friends' fathers" exemplifies how Saburo was more modernized and more impressionable than his father; how he looked at change verses how his father saw it. As time progresses, and Saburo matures, we see how his relationship with his father also matures, and how he seems him in a completely different light than before.

data_answer: Though Saburo and his father's relationship might not seem affectionate to one's naked eye, their relationship is stronger than it seems. To Saburo and his father, their bond of accomplishing something together was an expression of what people might call the "stereotypical-father-son" relationship. For example, when Saburo quit the track team to focus on his college entrance examinations, he "felt guilty over ending their sessions", in other words, he loved that time he had spent with his father. As Saburo grew up, he realized his father had a "passionate side". According to Saburo's youthful experience, his father was a stoic man, but Saburo learned that he was indeed his father's son.
